description: I just needed something simple for designing my DIY furniture, this tool is perfect. Simple, yet powerful enough.

It is in the name but one very cool feature of OpenSCAD is the ability to define variables in your cad file then set those variable with command like parameters when exporting the script. This allows another program to generate models with programmatically defined parameters.
On Ubuntu 18.04, it crashes when I try to open any example, even those shipped with the program.

My Operating System is Ubuntu 18.04

 I have now used this application for around a year, mainly for designing a great number of 3D printed items The majority being storage boxes to go in my workshop storage cabinets - for screws, nuts, bolts, washers etc etc etc.

To date I've designed and produced well over 120 storage boxes, with about 20 different designs and dimensions. I've also designed and produced the inevitable flower pots and vases for the Lady of the House.

I found it fairly easy to learn the basics and produce simple shapes. Then, as I began to learn more complex shapes I found that as I was now recognising the coding structure, I was learning the more complex coding much quicker.

I have found it extremely quick and easy to produce very accurately dimensioned storage boxes of various sizes, and some nesting versions, which allows me to maximise storage of smaller items.i.e. two smaller boxes accurately fitting inside one larger box. This has given me great flexibility for storage, plus when necessary I can create the code for a new sized box in about 10 to 15 minutes.

It was also quite easy to create boxes with rounded corners to accurately nest inside larger storage trays.

I still find it useful when creating the code, to place annotations at the end of the lines of code in order to remind me the function of that line - just like the 'Rem' function that was used in QuickBasic. In OpenSCad the same effect is achieved using a double forward slash - '//'. 

I also use the '//' to place critical dimensions and other info at the top of the code page so I have a quick reference to hand.

By having 'plain language' at the end of each line makes it very easy to know exactly where to quickly 'tweak' and adjust the design.

Once the design is completed and Saved, it is then exported to another folder as an STL file. I then use the Prussa Slicer application (also found on Ubuntu) to import the ST file, 'Slice' the design into Gcode, and then Save the Gcode to take to my 3D Printer. (I've described all this in case someone reading it is not yet too familiar with 3D printing but contemplating having a go at designing)

For the time being, OpenSCad does all I require of a design application for 3D printing. If I was to look at a far more complex design, I suspect this application may struggle with extensive code, so I have given 4 stars out of 5.

Thanks for reading this far. I hope it helps you.

Thisisi
summary: I use it extensively for creating designs for 3D printing

description: Good for designing models to 3D print

When you want precise control over the model(s) you build, and you want to be able reuse components you create, well, that's where the WYSIWYG, click-and-drag tools come up short and OpenSCAD may be a better choice.

Models are created by invoking "modules" and passing them parameters. Users can package elements of their own models as "modules," stash them in a "libarary" and reuse then across any number of models.

The parametric thinking that OpenSCAD encourages (requires?) come pretty naturally to programmers, mathematicians and the like, but may not comfortable for others.

I use OpenSCAD primarily for designing 3D-printable enclosures for electronics (see web site: 3dcd.us). I developed a set of function and modules containing many reusable enclosure elements ("snap fits," "friction fits," "fan supports," etc.). OpenSCAD shines for these kinds of models.

While OpenSCAD might be useful for producing artistic works of geometric natures and themes, it is not generally well-suited to other artistic endeavors.
summary: Fine example of First-Class open source program

description: leider bootet das Programm an meinem Rechner nicht, zumindest nicht augenscheinlich

This program is very usefull to compute some complicated structures that can be described by a simple mathematical description.
It could be even better if the language of OpenSCAD was an already existing language (e.g. Python), if there where no memory leaks (I have to quit and go back to restore the memory between computations), and if some bugs could be solved (for example it does'nt compute correctly the Minkowski sum of complicated examples, but without giving any error or warning message).
